snippet.textDisplay:
Baaaaaaaaad recommendations everywhere.

What happens when a drive dies?? How do you find the dead one? How do you swap it easily? Can you do it when the system is running to save time/money?

If there are any actual professionals watching this vid and thinking they'd like to do a build like this, DON'T. These "shortcuts" cost a lot of time and sanity later down the line that can completely neutralize the cash you saved on the bad-use-case case (pin intended).

Linus, your videos are usually more well thought out than this. Please peer review your concepts before doing this much work.
snippet.textOriginal:
Baaaaaaaaad recommendations everywhere.

What happens when a drive dies?? How do you find the dead one? How do you swap it easily? Can you do it when the system is running to save time/money?

If there are any actual professionals watching this vid and thinking they'd like to do a build like this, DON'T. These "shortcuts" cost a lot of time and sanity later down the line that can completely neutralize the cash you saved on the bad-use-case case (pin intended).

Linus, your videos are usually more well thought out than this. Please peer review your concepts before doing this much work.

snippet.textDisplay:
Todays nerdiest thing competitors, respect https://www.alibaba.com/product-detail/Wholesale-IC-Chips-transistors-C2M0080120D-Integrated_62480340211.html?spm=a2700.gallery_search_cps.normalList.1.2dd23dd4ivzTUJ
1.2kv 30A at 40Mhz, because you can only switch current, you would need a variac every time you wanted to change voltage. Gravity is 10m/s^2, so your angular acceleration is also your torque. Its much easier to multiply voltage than current, thus the ultimate nerd product.
snippet.textOriginal:
Todays nerdiest thing competitors, respect https://www.alibaba.com/product-detail/Wholesale-IC-Chips-transistors-C2M0080120D-Integrated_62480340211.html?spm=a2700.gallery_search_cps.normalList.1.2dd23dd4ivzTUJ
1.2kv 30A at 40Mhz, because you can only switch current, you would need a variac every time you wanted to change voltage.  Gravity is 10m/s^2, so your angular acceleration is also your torque.  Its much easier to multiply voltage than current, thus the ultimate nerd product.

snippet.textDisplay:
This talk about the data distribution is concerning me..... if you have an even number of drives that are all the same size, then their free space should always be IDENTICAL, or else you don't have true parity. In this kind of software RAID, there's no such thing as "the disk with the most amount of free space" or "bottleneck(ing) by the speed of the one or two drives a certain file resides on".
If you have enough parity to lose two disks, that means ANY two disks. If you have parity at all, that means that every file is stored on every drive evenly to the point that ANY two disks can fail, and the file still exists evenly across the remaining drives.

Is Linus mistaken or is Unraid actually that terrible?
snippet.textOriginal:
This talk about the data distribution is concerning me..... if you have an even number of drives that are all the same size, then their free space should always be IDENTICAL, or else you don't have true parity. In this kind of software RAID, there's no such thing as "the disk with the most amount of free space" or "bottleneck(ing) by the speed of the one or two drives a certain file resides on".
If you have enough parity to lose two disks, that means ANY two disks. If you have parity at all, that means that every file is stored on every drive evenly to the point that ANY two disks can fail, and the file still exists evenly across the remaining drives.

Is Linus mistaken or is Unraid actually that terrible?

snippet.textDisplay: For ease of use, unraid is worth every cent. If you were really trying to build a 'budget' NAS, pair an HBA with a reasonable sized used computer. Especially seeing he has this set up for just serving data and not running VMs or Plex, an old Dell could get you going so you can focus on what will actually bankrupt you; the drives.
snippet.textOriginal: For ease of use, unraid is worth every cent. If you were really trying to build a 'budget' NAS, pair an HBA with a reasonable sized used computer. Especially seeing he has this set up for just serving data and not running VMs or Plex, an old Dell could get you going so you can focus on what will actually bankrupt you; the drives.

snippet.textDisplay: Those SAS to SATA cables can be a bear. It's not just a matter of matching the connectors up, but they also have directionality (ie: crossover-ness). Some cables are intended so be plugged straight into an HBA/RAID card, while others are supposed to be plugged into a backplane. As specialty cables, they're also surprisingly expensive.
snippet.textOriginal: Those SAS to SATA cables can be a bear. It's not just a matter of matching the connectors up, but they also have directionality (ie: crossover-ness). Some cables are intended so be plugged straight into an HBA/RAID card, while others are supposed to be plugged into a backplane. As specialty cables, they're also surprisingly expensive.

snippet.textDisplay:
you need to recheck the Prices

snippet.textDisplay: Hey, you guys should check out OpenMediaVault. It's a Debian based NAS distro similar to FreeNAS. It has a plugin for MergerFS which gives you drive pooling just like unRAID and then you can use the Snapraid plugin for parity. You can run it in a VM in Proxmox, too.
snippet.textOriginal: Hey, you guys should check out OpenMediaVault. It's a Debian based NAS distro similar to FreeNAS. It has a plugin for MergerFS which gives you drive pooling just like unRAID and then you can use the Snapraid plugin for parity. You can run it in a VM in Proxmox, too.

snippet.textDisplay:
Let's build a nonsensical NAS server with random parts we have laying around the office so we have a video and get to keep the drives seagate sent us.
This video is a complete mess. 
A "budget" build claim but is a $1000 NAS without any drives. Then goes ahead and adds $10,000 in drives to this "budget" build. 
A $11,000 build using random outdated consumer parts and an overpriced full tower case with terrible airflow.
Spends 5 minutes explaining why Unraid isn't suitable and that they are using proxmox but later shows them using unraid with no explanation why they went against using proxmox.

Would be better off buying second hand enterprise gear. look at this 96TB build for $2,500 with drives: (https://www.bargainhardware.co.uk/supermicro-cse-x9dri-f-846-24-lff-configure-to-order?c_b=11252)

SuperMicro (4U) Case with 24x 3.5" Hot swap bays
2 x 10-Core, 2.50Ghz, Xeons
96GB ECC Memory
96TB SAS HDDs
2 x SuperMicro Hot Swap 1200W PSUs
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
Nice video but bad idea, much better using an old server you can find for cheap with alot of memory (+96Gb)
with appropriate ventilation end proper cable management with a good backplate and a supplementary server rack disk enclosure.
Spend this money for all this HD in a case that is not build for that is really risky.
If you use FreeNAS use one NVMe SSD (512gb or 1Tb) for L2ARC and ZIL together with 96Gb of RAM and dual 10Gbe NIC you can work seamlessly with more WS sharing files on the same NAS.
Furthermore using a MB without remote management for a NAS is very bad idea.
You can spend less money with some very good refurbished server equipment than with this Frankenstein configuration.
snippet.textOriginal:
Nice video but bad idea, much better using an old server you can find for cheap with alot of memory (+96Gb)

snippet.textDisplay: Because the current & future SSD shortage, I'm build my full SSD storage right now. And I found something interesting on Taobao. There are 5.25inch sized 6x 2.5inch toolless hard drive bay, which means I can fit 6 SSDs in on single drive bay. And there also are CD burning chassis that have 12 drive bays. This means I can fit 6 * 12 = 72 drives in one single chassis which even blows 45drive(currently have 32drive max for full SSD storage) away >.<
snippet.textOriginal: Because the current & future SSD shortage, I'm build my full SSD storage right now. And I found something interesting on Taobao. There are 5.25inch sized 6x 2.5inch toolless hard drive bay, which means I can fit 6 SSDs in on single drive bay. And there also are CD burning chassis that have 12 drive bays. This means I can fit 6 * 12 = 72 drives in one single chassis which even blows 45drive(currently have 32drive max for full SSD storage) away >.<

snippet.textDisplay:
I get you guys needed to do a video so you didn't have to send these drives back to Seagate but this build is a bit weird.
In the UK these drives are about £460-500 so we're looking at £9,200 worth of drives before we get to the system. At that price ECC ram, a server-grade chassis, board and CPU isn't pushing the boat out. I'd assume a system like this would require high availability and quick turnaround for any faulty parts so redundant PSUs, hot-swap sleds and good airflow over the HBA/NIC would be a must.
snippet.textOriginal:
I get you guys needed to do a video so you didn't have to send these drives back to Seagate but this build is a bit weird.
In the UK these drives are about £460-500 so we're looking at £9,200 worth of drives before we get to the system. At that price ECC ram, a server-grade chassis, board and CPU isn't pushing the boat out. I'd assume a system like this would require high availability and quick turnaround for any faulty parts so redundant PSUs, hot-swap sleds and good airflow over the HBA/NIC would be a must.

snippet.textDisplay: Never use RAID-Z1 or RAID 5. If a drive fails it will take a long time to rebuild and during that time if another drives fails you are screwed.

snippet.textDisplay: why you never RAID0 lets say 3 drives together and run RAID0 drives in UNRAID. It improves the read/write speeds. I've done this with old 500Gb drives and created 3 raid0 2TB (4x500GB) drives and it saturates 1GBit network easily :) Maybe idea for your next UNRAID video...
snippet.textOriginal: why you never RAID0 lets say 3 drives together and run RAID0 drives in UNRAID. It improves the read/write speeds. I've done this with old 500Gb drives and created 3 raid0 2TB (4x500GB) drives and it saturates 1GBit network easily :) Maybe idea for your next UNRAID video...

snippet.textDisplay:
First, one should NOT use SAS controllers with SATA drives. You can, of course, but you must make sure to have 1 to 1 connector to drive connection, and NOT using SAS expanders.
SAS expanders have active parts (chip that converts one SAS connection to more ports) and those chip can be buggy, glitchy or just stuck in the middle of the operations, at random, so with them your system can got stuck, just for using SAS expanders.
And please, just use ZFS for your file server, it is multi platform it is 15 years in production.
(and ECC RAM seems like obligatory these days, if you dont' want the garbled data to end up keeps writing on your file server..- Intel guys without ECC, please pay attention..) .

Another problem in the amateurish system like this, is the huge vibration coming from differently oriented drives, without enough vibration isolation. Maybe if they are oriented in the same way, system would be less vibrations-affected?
Also case that is used is hugely important for easing access to drives in case of the need for drive replacement. (I always like more RADIZ2 then RAIDZ with spare drives... Just saying for spare drive to kick in, it takes time, but if drive is already there.. why not putting it full time on the task of better guarding data?.. just saying..)

It is NOT the case that you can not add different sized drives in their own VDEVs (groups of drives) over time. you can, and also your whole disks system gets faster with the number of VDEVs you are adding to the system. (data is striped across VDEVs)
Of course VDEVs should consist of at least pairs of drives at minimum for error resiliency, when adding more drives to the system.
Also one can also REPLACE smaller capacity drives, with a larger drives (by replacing ALL drives in the VDEV, you get free space increase in that VDEV), and do that on the fly
Also with newest OpenZFS development, one can also REMOVE some VDEVs form the system and add a new ones, and ZFS would reconfigure data.
Only someone stupid could rely to adding ONE drive at a time, to expand File server capacity and loose all the goodness of ZFS in the process, plus limiting writing speed..
snippet.textOriginal:
First, one should NOT use SAS controllers with SATA drives. You can, of course, but you must make sure to have 1 to 1 connector to drive connection, and NOT using SAS expanders. 
SAS expanders have active parts (chip that converts one SAS connection to more ports) and those chip can be buggy, glitchy or just stuck in the middle of the operations, at random, so with them your system can got stuck, just for using SAS expanders. 
And please, just use ZFS for your file server, it is multi platform it is 15 years in production. 
(and ECC RAM seems like obligatory these days, if you dont' want the garbled data to end up keeps writing on your file server..- Intel guys without ECC, please pay attention..) . 

Another problem in the amateurish system like this,  is the huge vibration coming from differently oriented drives, without enough vibration isolation. Maybe if they are oriented in the same way, system would be less vibrations-affected?
Also case that is used is hugely important for easing access to drives in case of the need for drive replacement. (I always like more RADIZ2 then RAIDZ with spare drives... Just saying for spare drive to kick in, it takes time, but if drive is already there.. why not putting it full time on the task of better guarding data?.. just saying..)

It is NOT the case that you can not add different sized drives in their own VDEVs (groups of drives) over time. you can, and also your whole disks system gets faster with the number of VDEVs you are adding to the system. (data is striped across VDEVs)
Of course VDEVs should consist of at least pairs of drives at minimum for error resiliency, when adding more drives to the system.
Also one can also REPLACE smaller capacity drives, with a larger drives (by replacing ALL drives in the VDEV, you get free space increase in that VDEV), and do that _on the fly_ 
Also with newest OpenZFS development, one can also REMOVE some VDEVs form the system and add a new ones, and ZFS would reconfigure data. 
Only someone stupid could rely to adding ONE drive at a time, to expand File server capacity and loose all the goodness of ZFS in the process, plus limiting writing speed..

snippet.textDisplay: Thanks for reminding me that HBA cards and "octopus" cables are still relatively cheap! Also you can go without a VGA card at all. Linux naturally supports ttys redirected to serial ports. You just have to reconfigure your installer's GRUB or use preseed instead. I guess every UEFI has PXE or BOOTP support nowadays. It's not for just the server market anymore.
snippet.textOriginal: Thanks for reminding me that HBA cards and "octopus" cables are still relatively cheap! Also you can go without a VGA card at all. Linux naturally supports ttys redirected to serial ports. You just have to reconfigure your installer's GRUB or use preseed instead. I guess every UEFI has PXE or BOOTP support nowadays. It's not for just the server market anymore.

snippet.textDisplay: Don't do RaidZ1 with such large drives. If a drive dies the resilvering process could easily kill another drive due to the strain of resilvering - bye bye data
snippet.textOriginal: Don't do RaidZ1 with such large drives. If a drive dies the resilvering process could easily kill another drive due to the strain of resilvering - bye bye data

snippet.textDisplay: If you are building a server, use server class hardware. If you were building a super car, you wouldn't start with a Yugo.

snippet.textDisplay:
Is there gonna be detailed tutorial?

I'm tech savvy but do not have almost any experience about nas setup or commandline stuff, also I have built only 1 pc so far. So all those parts I need as a list
